title: Gus W. Dorsey
text:
Gustavus Warfield Dorsey (April 20, 1839 – September 6, 1911) was a <a href="cavalry">cavalry</a> commander during the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a> for the <a href="Confederate%20States%20of%20America">Confederacy</a>. When famed cavalry commander <a href="Jeb%20Stuart">Jeb Stuart</a> was shot at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Yellow%20Tavern">Battle of Yellow Tavern</a> and mortally wounded, he fell into Dorsey's arms.
Early years.
G. W. Dorsey was born to Samuel Owings Dorsey and Mary Riggs Griffith on April 20, 1839, a descendant of <a href="Edward%20Dorsey%20%28shipwright%29">Edward Dorsey</a> of <a href="colonial%20Maryland">colonial Maryland</a>. He had three sisters and a brother. He married Maggie Owens.
Civil War.
He enlisted on May 14, 1861 for Company K of the <a href="1st%20Virginia%20Cavalry">1st Virginia Cavalry</a>. He became a <a href="lieutenant%20colonel">lieutenant colonel</a> in May 1862, and after the death of his unit's commander Ridgely Brown, he commanded the regiment. He was wounded at <a href="Battle%20of%20Fredericksburg">Fredericksburg</a>.
His unit was later transferred to 1st Maryland Cavalry in August, 1864. He was severely wounded at <a href="Battle%20of%20Fisher%27s%20Hill">Fisher's Hill</a>.
Yellow Tavern.
Stuart rode up to give words of praise to Company K and was shot in the stomach. Dorsey caught him and took him from his horse. Stuart told him: "Dorsey...save your men." Dorsey refused to leave him and brought Stuart to the rear.
